noun.description: An imaginary line on the earth's surface cutting all meridians at the same angle, used as the standard method of plotting a ship's course on a chart.
Any of the 32 points of the compass.

origin: Late 16th century: from French rumb (earlier ryn (de vent) point of the compass), probably from Dutch ruim space, room. The spelling change was due to association with Latin rhombus (see rhombus).
